solutions.title: unique-solution-beats-98-in-run-time
solutions.content:
I guess nobody shared this solution.

This is a bit log and it is different approach


If you liked this **please upvote.**

```Bash 
# Read from the file words.txt and output the word frequency list to stdout.
declare -A hm
max=0
while IFS=' ' read -r -a line
do
    for value in ${line[@]} 
        do 
            # echo $value
            if [[ hm[$value] == -1 ]]
                then 
                hm[$value]=1
                else 
                (( hm[$value]+=1 ))
                [[ hm[$value] -gt max ]] && (( max=hm[$value] ))
            fi 
        done
done < "words.txt"
declare -A another
for value in ${!hm[@]}; do 
if [[ another[${hm[$value]}] -eq -1 ]] ; then another[${hm[$value]}]=() ; fi
another[${hm[$value]}]+=$value
done
while [ $max -gt 0 ] 
do
if [[ another[$max] -ne -1 ]]
then
for el in ${another[$max]}; do
echo "${another[$max]} $max"
done
fi
(( max-=1 ))
done
```

Last but not the least
This is one Liner solution

cat words.txt | tr -s ' ' '\n' | sort | uniq --count | sort -r | awk '{print $2 " " $1}'

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
*Detailed explanation of the bash script:
1. tr -s ' ' '\n' < words.txt

This command uses the tr utility to replace all occurrences of one or more spaces with a newline character (\n). The -s option squeezes repeated characters to a single character, so it ensures that consecutive spaces are treated as a single separator. The input for this command is read from the file words.txt.

2. sort :

This command sorts the words alphabetically. Each word appears on a separate line thanks to the tr command.


3. uniq -c :

This command counts the frequency of each unique word. The -c option makes uniq output the count of each group of identical lines (i.e., each unique word).

4. sort -nr :

This command sorts the output of uniq by frequency in descending order. The -n option tells sort to sort numerically, while the -r option tells it to sort in reverse order (i.e., descending).


5. awk '{print $2, $1}' :

This command uses awk to print the second field (the word) followed by the first field (the frequency), separated by a space. The output is sorted by frequency in descending order.

So overall, the script reads a text file words.txt, replaces all occurrences of one or more spaces with a newline character, sorts the resulting words alphabetically, counts the frequency of each unique word, sorts the words by frequency in descending order, and finally prints each word followed by its frequency separated by a space.
*

solutions.title: 192-word-frequency
solutions.content:
# Intuition
Here's a bash script that uses tr, sort, uniq, and awk commands to calculate the frequency of each word in a text file words.txt:

# Approach
Here's how it works:

tr -s ' ' '\n' < words.txt replaces every space character with a newline character, effectively converting the file into a list of words, one per line.
sort sorts the list of words in lexicographic order.
uniq -c counts the number of occurrences of each word and outputs the count followed by the word.
awk '{print $2 " " $1}' rearranges the output to have the word followed by its count.
sort -rn -k2 sorts the output in reverse numerical order based on the second field (the count).

# Complexity
The time and space complexity of the bash script to calculate the frequency of each word in a text file words.txt depends on the size of the input file and the number of distinct words in the file.

Let's analyze the individual commands used in the script:

tr -s ' ' '\n': This command reads the input file and replaces every space character with a newline character. The time complexity of this command is O(n), where n is the size of the input file. The space complexity is O(1), since the command only needs to store a few characters at a time.

sort: This command sorts the list of words in lexicographic order. The time complexity of this command is O(n log n), where n is the number of words in the input file. The space complexity is O(n), since the command needs to store the list of words in memory to perform the sort.

uniq -c: This command counts the number of occurrences of each word and outputs the count followed by the word. The time complexity of this command is O(n), where n is the number of words in the input file. The space complexity is O(n), since the command needs to store the list of words and their counts in memory.

awk '{print $2 " " $1}': This command rearranges the output to have the word followed by its count. The time complexity of this command is O(n), where n is the number of words in the input file. The space complexity is O(n), since the command needs to store the list of words and their counts in memory.

sort -rn -k2: This command sorts the output in reverse numerical order based on the second field (the count). The time complexity of this command is O(n log n), where n is the number of distinct words in the input file. The space complexity is O(n), since the command needs to store the list of words and their counts in memory.

Overall, the time complexity of the script is O(n log n), where n is the number of words in the input file. The space complexity of the script is O(n), where n is the number of distinct words in the input file.

```
# Read from the file words.txt and output the word frequency list to stdout.

solutions.title: solution-step-by-step-explanation
solutions.content:
Here's a bash script to calculate the frequency of each word in a text file named **words.txt**. The script uses **awk** to split the input file into individual words and then uses **sort** and uniq to count the frequency of each word. Finally, **sort** is used again to **sort** the output by descending frequency.


> # Code
```
#!/bin/bash


cat words.txt | awk '{for(i=1;i<=NF;i++) print $i}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn | awk '{print $2 " " $1}'
```


- **Explanation**:

1. ***cat words.txt***: The cat command outputs the contents of the words.txt file to the standard output stream.
2. **awk {for(i=1;i<=NF;i++) print $i}**: The awk command splits each line of the input stream into individual words and outputs them to the standard output stream, one per line.
3. **tr -s ' ' '\n'**: The tr command replaces all occurrences of the space character with a newline character, effectively splitting each line into individual words.
4. **sort**: The sort command sorts the input alphabetically.
5. **uniq -c**: The uniq command removes consecutive duplicate lines from the input and outputs the count of how many times each line occurred.
6. **sort -rn**: The second sort command sorts the output by the count of each word in descending order.

cat words.txt | awk '{for(i=1;i<=NF;i++) print $i}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn | awk '{print $2 " " $1}'
```

# Code
```
#!/bin/bash

i=0
for word in $(cat words.txt)
do
    j=0
    flag=0
    while [ $j -lt $i -a $flag -eq 0 ]
    do
        if [ "${wordList[$j]}" == "$word" ]
        then
            let freq[$j]=freq[$j]+1
            flag=1
        fi
        let j=j+1
    done

    if [ $flag -eq 0 ]
    then
        wordList[$i]="$word"
        freq[$i]=1
        let i=i+1
    fi
done

if [ $i -eq 0 ]
then
    exit 0
fi

k=0
while [ $k -lt $i ]
do
    wordList[$k]="${wordList[$k]} ${freq[$k]}"
    let k=k+1
done

printf "%s\n" "${wordList[@]}" | sort -k 2,2nr -k 1,1

exit 0
```

#!/bin/sh
t=$(cat words.txt | tr '\n' ' ' | tr -s ' ' | tr ' ' '\n' | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | sed "s/^[[:blank:]]*//g;s/[[:blank:]]*$//g")
while read -r dat
do
        echo $(echo $dat | tac -s ' ')
done <<< $t

```

solutions.title: bash-script-arrays
solutions.content:
# Intuition
Read word by word the input text file and keep track of words read and update their absolute frequency with a counter.
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
I used two vectors:
1. wordList to keep track of words in the text
2. freq to count the absolute freq of the words in wordList

For the same index i, the two vectors show the word with its absolute frequency.
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity: $$O(n^2)$$
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity: $$O(n)$$
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
#!/bin/bash

i=0
for word in $(cat words.txt)
do
    j=0
    flag=0
    while [ $j -lt $i -a $flag -eq 0 ]
    do
        if [ "${wordList[$j]}" == "$word" ]
        then
            let freq[$j]=freq[$j]+1
            flag=1
        fi
        let j=j+1
    done

    if [ $flag -eq 0 ]
    then
        wordList[$i]="$word"
        freq[$i]=1
        let i=i+1
    fi
done

if [ $i -eq 0 ]
then
    exit 0
fi

k=0
while [ $k -lt $i ]
do
    wordList[$k]="${wordList[$k]} ${freq[$k]}"
    let k=k+1
done

printf "%s\n" "${wordList[@]}" | sort -k 2,2nr -k 1,1

exit 0
```

solutions.title: associative-array-bash-style
solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
# Read from the file words.txt and output the word frequency list to stdout.

file=words.txt

declare -A array
cnt=1

while read line
do
     for word in $line
     do
       if [ -n "${array[$word]}" ]
       then
          array["$word"]=$((${array["$word"]} + 1))
       else
         array["$word"]=1
       fi
     done
done < $file

for key in "${!array[@]}"
do
echo $key ${array[$key]}
done | sort -k2rn

```

solutions.title: use-tr
solutions.content:
```bash
tr -cs "[:alpha:]" "\n" < words.txt | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk '{print $2" "$1}'
```

1. `tr -cs "[:alpha:]" "\n" < words.txt ` One word perline
2. `sort | uniq -c` Precede each output line with the count of the number of times the line occurred
3. `sort -r` Descending sort order
4. `awk '{print $2" "$1}'` Output becareful space between two column


For example:

words.txt
```txt
the day is sunny the the
the sunny is is
a  a   b
```

```bash
tr -cs "[:alpha:]" "\n" < words.txt

the
day
is
sunny
the
the
the
sunny
is
is
a
a
b
```

```bash
tr -cs "[:alpha:]" "\n" < words.txt | sort | uniq -c | sort -r
   4 the
   3 is
   2 sunny
   2 a
   1 day
   1 b
```

```bash
tr -cs "[:alpha:]" "\n" < words.txt | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk '{print $2" "$1}'
the 4
is 3
sunny 2
a 2
day 1
b 1
```

non-one-liner-s-benefits-memory-usage-3-1-mb-less-than-95-77
solutions.content:
```
declare -r input_file="words.txt"

if ! [[ -f "${input_file}" ]]; then
    exit 1
fi

unset -v words_freq
declare -A words_freq

# Collect data from file
while IFS= read -r line || [ -n "$line" ]; do
    for word in ${line}; do ((words_freq[$word]++)); done
done < ${input_file}

# Output data sorted by frequency
for word in ${!words_freq[@]}
do
    echo -e "${word} ${words_freq[$word]}"
done | sort -rn -k2

```

solutions.title: just-simple-awk
0-ms-3-1-mb-background-task-with-for-loop
solutions.content:
```
#!/bin/bash
many=$(sed 's/ /\n/g' words.txt)
for word in $(printf "$many" | sort -u)
do
	printf "%s %d\n" $word $(printf "$many" | grep -w $word | wc -l) &
done | sort -nru -k2
```

The key is to add the ```&``` to the end of the grep. This launches it as a background process. Without executing the grep operation as a background task, it takes 4 ms.

another way(using loop and array) but it is not  the solution for this qustion 
My script 
```

#/bin/bash
#script will get how many times the word is repeated 
#there might be other ways much much better than what i wrote
#file path
file=$1
#store all words in this array
arr=()
#store Unique Words
arrU=()

#loop in file and store the words in this arr
for word in $(cat $file);
do
arr=("${arr[@]}" "$word")
done

if [[ "${#arr[@]}" -gt 0 ]];then
arrU=("${arr[0]}")
# loop and store value in this arrU if no match was found
for w in "${arr[@]}";
do
  check=false
  for wu in "${arrU[@]}";
  do
	if [[ "$w" = "$wu" ]];then
		check=true
	fi
  done
 
if [[ "$check" = false ]];then
    arrU=("${arrU[@]}" "$w")
fi
done

#count how many time the word is repeated
for wu in "${arrU[@]}";
do
  count=0
  for w in "${arr[@]}";
  do
	if [[ "$w" = "$wu" ]];then
		count=$((count + 1))	
	fi 
  done
 echo "$wu $count"
done

else
echo "File is empty"
fi

```

usage

```
./frequency.sh words.txt | sort -rk 2

solutions.title: funny-solution
help-why-did-i-get-wrong-answer-with-the-same-output-as-expected
solutions.content:
```
# Read from the file words.txt and output the word frequency list to stdout.
#!/bin/bash

n="$( cat words.txt | tr ' ' '\n' | sort  | uniq -c | tr -s ' ' | cut -d " " -f 3,2 )"
r=""
let count=0
for i in $n
do

    (( $count%2==0 )) && (( $count>1 )) && r="\n$r"
    let count++
    r="$i $r"

done
echo -e "$r"
```
![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/yyuze/image_1580747168.png)
solutions.code:
```
# Read from the file words.txt and output the word frequency list to stdout.
#!/bin/bash

n="$( cat words.txt | tr ' ' '\n' | sort  | uniq -c | tr -s ' ' | cut -d " " -f 3,2 )"
r=""
let count=0
for i in $n
do

    (( $count%2==0 )) && (( $count>1 )) && r="\n$r"
    let count++
    r="$i $r"

done
echo -e "$r"
```

solutions.title: my-solution
solutions.content:
```
list=($(cat words.txt | awk "/[a-z]+/"))
printf "%s\n" "${list[@]}" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k2 -r -n | awk '{printf "%s %s\n", $2, $1}'
```
First I put all the lowercase words inside of an array. The OFS will automatically separate the array by space
Next I print out sort the array by uniqueness and output the count as well. Since the fields should be switched and not sorted by descending order, I put it through another sort and pipe it to another awk, where I switch the fields.
solutions.code:
```
list=($(cat words.txt | awk "/[a-z]+/"))
printf "%s\n" "${list[@]}" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k2 -r -n | awk '{printf "%s %s\n", $2, $1}'
```

solutions.title: easy-to-understand-iteration-associative-array
solutions.content:
```bash
declare -A WORD_FREQ_TABLE

cat words.txt |
(while read line; do
    for word in $line; do
	# if the word does not exist
	if [ ${WORD_FREQ_TABLE["$word"]+_} ]; then
	    WORD_FREQ_TABLE["$word"]=$(( WORD_FREQ_TABLE["$word"] + 1 ))
	else
	    WORD_FREQ_TABLE["$word"]=1
	fi
    done
done

for item in "${!WORD_FREQ_TABLE[@]}"; do
    echo "$item"  ${WORD_FREQ_TABLE["$item"]}
done | sort -r -k2 -n)
solutions.code:
```bash
declare -A WORD_FREQ_TABLE

cat words.txt |
(while read line; do
    for word in $line; do
	# if the word does not exist
	if [ ${WORD_FREQ_TABLE["$word"]+_} ]; then
	    WORD_FREQ_TABLE["$word"]=$(( WORD_FREQ_TABLE["$word"] + 1 ))
	else
	    WORD_FREQ_TABLE["$word"]=1
	fi
    done
done

for item in "${!WORD_FREQ_TABLE[@]}"; do
    echo "$item"  ${WORD_FREQ_TABLE["$item"]}
done | sort -r -k2 -n)

solutions.title: one-line-with-pipes
solutions.content: ```\ncat words.txt | tr -s " " "\\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | awk \'{print $2 " " $1}\'\n```
solutions.code: ```\ncat words.txt | tr -s " " "\\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | awk \'{print $2 " " $1}\'\n```

content.content: tr -s ' ' '\\n' < words.txt|sort|uniq -c|sort -nr|awk '{print $2, $1}'
`cat words.txt | tr -s \' \' \'\\n\' | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk \'{print $2" "$1}\'`
cat words.txt | tr -cs "[a-z]" "\\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k1nr -k2 |awk \'{print $2,$1}\'\n

cat words.txt | tr '\n' ' ' | sed "s/\s\s*/ /g" | awk -v RS=' ' '{print $0}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr -k1 | awk '{print $2" "$1}'

**cat word.txt** :
output the text in the file

**tr '\n' ' '** :
substitute endlines with single space

**sed "s/\s\s*/ /g"** :
substitute multiple spaces with single space

**awk -v RS=' ' '{print $0}'** :
output one word per line by changing Record Separator in AWK to single space. $0 is the entire record (1 word).

**sort** :
sort alphabetically the list of words (with repetitions) to prepare it for uniq command.

**uniq -c** :
print the list of unique words with their count. Before uniq you need to sort the list of words.

**sort -nr -k1** :
sort the list of unique words by their count  (-nr numerical reverse sorting) (-k1 sort by the first field that is the count of repetitions for the current word)

**awk '{print $2" "$1}'** :
for each line print before the second field $2, that is the word, and then the first field that is the count of repetitions for the word.

`echo `cat words.txt` | tr "[:space:]+" "\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k 1nr | sed 's/^ *//g' | awk '{print $2 " " $1}'`

1. Pipe in content of words.txt
2. Translate one or more spaces into newlines
3. Sort the file line by line, ascending
4. Count how many times each of the lines appears in the file (output will be two columns: first is count, second is line
5. Sort the output 
	* -k: sort by key (in this case column, pairs with -t)
	* 1: sort by firt column
	* -n: sort as a number
	* -r: reverse order
6. Remove any leading whitespace using sed
7. Print the output as second column, then space, then first column

for word in `cat words.txt`;do echo $word; done|sort|uniq -c|sort -r|awk '{print $2,$1}'


used *for* with cat to cycle through each word in the txt file.

then used *sort* to output by word

used *uniq* to count unique words

used *sort -r* to reverse the order as descending

The output was backwards (count then word)
   4 the
   3 is
   2 sunny
   1 day
So used *awk* to reverse (word then count)
when python is largely avaibale, what\'s the point of using bash to process files?

You are not restricted from using python for this task. Just start with `python -c \'`and do whatever you want. However, you hardly can achieve one-line (not actually disadvantage), a pythonic solution most likely will be significantly slower than most of bash ones (true disadvantage).
grep -oE '[a-z]+' words.txt | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk '{print $2" "$1}' \n\nbut it costs 20ms.

sed 's/^\s\+//g; s/\s\+/ /g; s/\s\+$//g' words.txt | tr ' ' '\n' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | awk -F' ' '{print $2" "$1}'

1. use sed to strip head & tail spaces，and change inline spaces to one space
2. use tr to trans space to return (these two steps also can be done cat words.txt | tr -s ' ' '\n') 
3. sort the words
4. uniq to count words
5. sort the stats result，-n for numeric sort，-r for reverse
6. use awk to format the output

`awk \'{for (i = 1; i <= NF; i++) {cnt[$i]++}} END {for (w in cnt) {print w,cnt[w]}}\' words.txt | sort -k2nr`\n- Use `awk` to count how many times each word appears.\n- Sort the result descendingly using `sort` .
tr -s ' ' '\\n' < words.txt|sort|uniq -c|sort -nr|awk '{print $2, $1}'
`cat words.txt | tr -s \' \' \'\\n\' | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk \'{print $2" "$1}\'`
cat words.txt | tr -cs "[a-z]" "\\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k1nr -k2 |awk \'{print $2,$1}\'\n

cat words.txt | tr '\n' ' ' | sed "s/\s\s*/ /g" | awk -v RS=' ' '{print $0}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr -k1 | awk '{print $2" "$1}'

then used *sort* to output by word

used *uniq* to count unique words

used *sort -r* to reverse the order as descending

The output was backwards (count then word)
   4 the
   3 is
   2 sunny
   1 day
So used *awk* to reverse (word then count)
when python is largely avaibale, what\'s the point of using bash to process files?

You are not restricted from using python for this task. Just start with `python -c \'`and do whatever you want. However, you hardly can achieve one-line (not actually disadvantage), a pythonic solution most likely will be significantly slower than most of bash ones (true disadvantage).
grep -oE '[a-z]+' words.txt | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk '{print $2" "$1}' \n\nbut it costs 20ms.

sed 's/^\s\+//g; s/\s\+/ /g; s/\s\+$//g' words.txt | tr ' ' '\n' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | awk -F' ' '{print $2" "$1}'

1. use sed to strip head & tail spaces，and change inline spaces to one space
2. use tr to trans space to return (these two steps also can be done cat words.txt | tr -s ' ' '\n') 
3. sort the words
4. uniq to count words
5. sort the stats result，-n for numeric sort，-r for reverse
6. use awk to format the output

`awk \'{for (i = 1; i <= NF; i++) {cnt[$i]++}} END {for (w in cnt) {print w,cnt[w]}}\' words.txt | sort -k2nr`\n- Use `awk` to count how many times each word appears.\n- Sort the result descendingly using `sort` .
tr -s ' ' '\\n' < words.txt|sort|uniq -c|sort -nr|awk '{print $2, $1}'
`cat words.txt | tr -s \' \' \'\\n\' | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk \'{print $2" "$1}\'`
cat words.txt | tr -cs "[a-z]" "\\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k1nr -k2 |awk \'{print $2,$1}\'\n

cat words.txt | tr '\n' ' ' | sed "s/\s\s*/ /g" | awk -v RS=' ' '{print $0}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr -k1 | awk '{print $2" "$1}'

**cat word.txt** :
output the text in the file

**tr '\n' ' '** :
substitute endlines with single space

**sed "s/\s\s*/ /g"** :
substitute multiple spaces with single space

**awk -v RS=' ' '{print $0}'** :
output one word per line by changing Record Separator in AWK to single space. $0 is the entire record (1 word).

**sort** :
sort alphabetically the list of words (with repetitions) to prepare it for uniq command.

**uniq -c** :
print the list of unique words with their count. Before uniq you need to sort the list of words.

**sort -nr -k1** :
sort the list of unique words by their count  (-nr numerical reverse sorting) (-k1 sort by the first field that is the count of repetitions for the current word)

**awk '{print $2" "$1}'** :
for each line print before the second field $2, that is the word, and then the first field that is the count of repetitions for the word.

`echo `cat words.txt` | tr "[:space:]+" "\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k 1nr | sed 's/^ *//g' | awk '{print $2 " " $1}'`

1. Pipe in content of words.txt
2. Translate one or more spaces into newlines
3. Sort the file line by line, ascending
4. Count how many times each of the lines appears in the file (output will be two columns: first is count, second is line
5. Sort the output 
	* -k: sort by key (in this case column, pairs with -t)
	* 1: sort by firt column
	* -n: sort as a number
	* -r: reverse order
6. Remove any leading whitespace using sed
7. Print the output as second column, then space, then first column

for word in `cat words.txt`;do echo $word; done|sort|uniq -c|sort -r|awk '{print $2,$1}'


used *for* with cat to cycle through each word in the txt file.

then used *sort* to output by word

used *uniq* to count unique words

used *sort -r* to reverse the order as descending

The output was backwards (count then word)
   4 the
   3 is
   2 sunny
   1 day
So used *awk* to reverse (word then count)
when python is largely avaibale, what\'s the point of using bash to process files?

You are not restricted from using python for this task. Just start with `python -c \'`and do whatever you want. However, you hardly can achieve one-line (not actually disadvantage), a pythonic solution most likely will be significantly slower than most of bash ones (true disadvantage).
grep -oE '[a-z]+' words.txt | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk '{print $2" "$1}' \n\nbut it costs 20ms.

sed 's/^\s\+//g; s/\s\+/ /g; s/\s\+$//g' words.txt | tr ' ' '\n' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | awk -F' ' '{print $2" "$1}'

1. use sed to strip head & tail spaces，and change inline spaces to one space
2. use tr to trans space to return (these two steps also can be done cat words.txt | tr -s ' ' '\n') 
3. sort the words
4. uniq to count words
5. sort the stats result，-n for numeric sort，-r for reverse
6. use awk to format the output

`awk \'{for (i = 1; i <= NF; i++) {cnt[$i]++}} END {for (w in cnt) {print w,cnt[w]}}\' words.txt | sort -k2nr`\n- Use `awk` to count how many times each word appears.\n- Sort the result descendingly using `sort` .
tr -s ' ' '\\n' < words.txt|sort|uniq -c|sort -nr|awk '{print $2, $1}'
`cat words.txt | tr -s \' \' \'\\n\' | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk \'{print $2" "$1}\'`
cat words.txt | tr -cs "[a-z]" "\\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k1nr -k2 |awk \'{print $2,$1}\'\n

cat words.txt | tr '\n' ' ' | sed "s/\s\s*/ /g" | awk -v RS=' ' '{print $0}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr -k1 | awk '{print $2" "$1}'

**cat word.txt** :
output the text in the file

**tr '\n' ' '** :
substitute endlines with single space

**sed "s/\s\s*/ /g"** :
substitute multiple spaces with single space

**awk -v RS=' ' '{print $0}'** :
output one word per line by changing Record Separator in AWK to single space. $0 is the entire record (1 word).

**sort** :
sort alphabetically the list of words (with repetitions) to prepare it for uniq command.

**uniq -c** :
print the list of unique words with their count. Before uniq you need to sort the list of words.

**sort -nr -k1** :
sort the list of unique words by their count  (-nr numerical reverse sorting) (-k1 sort by the first field that is the count of repetitions for the current word)

**awk '{print $2" "$1}'** :
for each line print before the second field $2, that is the word, and then the first field that is the count of repetitions for the word.

`echo `cat words.txt` | tr "[:space:]+" "\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k 1nr | sed 's/^ *//g' | awk '{print $2 " " $1}'`

1. Pipe in content of words.txt
2. Translate one or more spaces into newlines
3. Sort the file line by line, ascending
4. Count how many times each of the lines appears in the file (output will be two columns: first is count, second is line
5. Sort the output 
	* -k: sort by key (in this case column, pairs with -t)
	* 1: sort by firt column
	* -n: sort as a number
	* -r: reverse order
6. Remove any leading whitespace using sed
7. Print the output as second column, then space, then first column

used *sort -r* to reverse the order as descending

6. Remove any leading whitespace using sed
7. Print the output as second column, then space, then first column

for word in `cat words.txt`;do echo $word; done|sort|uniq -c|sort -r|awk '{print $2,$1}'


used *for* with cat to cycle through each word in the txt file.

then used *sort* to output by word

used *uniq* to count unique words

used *sort -r* to reverse the order as descending

The output was backwards (count then word)
   4 the
   3 is
   2 sunny
   1 day
So used *awk* to reverse (word then count)
when python is largely avaibale, what\'s the point of using bash to process files?

You are not restricted from using python for this task. Just start with `python -c \'`and do whatever you want. However, you hardly can achieve one-line (not actually disadvantage), a pythonic solution most likely will be significantly slower than most of bash ones (true disadvantage).
grep -oE '[a-z]+' words.txt | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk '{print $2" "$1}' \n\nbut it costs 20ms.

sed 's/^\s\+//g; s/\s\+/ /g; s/\s\+$//g' words.txt | tr ' ' '\n' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | awk -F' ' '{print $2" "$1}'

1. use sed to strip head & tail spaces，and change inline spaces to one space
2. use tr to trans space to return (these two steps also can be done cat words.txt | tr -s ' ' '\n') 
3. sort the words
4. uniq to count words
5. sort the stats result，-n for numeric sort，-r for reverse
6. use awk to format the output

`awk \'{for (i = 1; i <= NF; i++) {cnt[$i]++}} END {for (w in cnt) {print w,cnt[w]}}\' words.txt | sort -k2nr`\n- Use `awk` to count how many times each word appears.\n- Sort the result descendingly using `sort` .
tr -s ' ' '\\n' < words.txt|sort|uniq -c|sort -nr|awk '{print $2, $1}'
`cat words.txt | tr -s \' \' \'\\n\' | sort | uniq -c | sort -r | awk \'{print $2" "$1}\'`
cat words.txt | tr -cs "[a-z]" "\\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k1nr -k2 |awk \'{print $2,$1}\'\n

cat words.txt | tr '\n' ' ' | sed "s/\s\s*/ /g" | awk -v RS=' ' '{print $0}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr -k1 | awk '{print $2" "$1}'

**cat word.txt** :
output the text in the file

**tr '\n' ' '** :
substitute endlines with single space

**sed "s/\s\s*/ /g"** :
substitute multiple spaces with single space

**awk -v RS=' ' '{print $0}'** :
output one word per line by changing Record Separator in AWK to single space. $0 is the entire record (1 word).

**sort** :
sort alphabetically the list of words (with repetitions) to prepare it for uniq command.

**uniq -c** :
print the list of unique words with their count. Before uniq you need to sort the list of words.

**sort -nr -k1** :
sort the list of unique words by their count  (-nr numerical reverse sorting) (-k1 sort by the first field that is the count of repetitions for the current word)

**awk '{print $2" "$1}'** :
for each line print before the second field $2, that is the word, and then the first field that is the count of repetitions for the word.

`echo `cat words.txt` | tr "[:space:]+" "\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k 1nr | sed 's/^ *//g' | awk '{print $2 " " $1}'`

1. Pipe in content of words.txt
2. Translate one or more spaces into newlines
3. Sort the file line by line, ascending
4. Count how many times each of the lines appears in the file (output will be two columns: first is count, second is line
5. Sort the output 
	* -k: sort by key (in this case column, pairs with -t)
	* 1: sort by firt column
	* -n: sort as a number
	* -r: reverse order
6. Remove any leading whitespace using sed
7. Print the output as second column, then space, then first column

then used *sort* to output by word

used *uniq* to count unique words

used *sort -r* to reverse the order as descending

`awk \'{for (i = 1; i <= NF; i++) {cnt[$i]++}} END {for (w in cnt) {print w,cnt[w]}}\' words.txt | sort -k2nr`\n- Use `awk` to count how many times each word appears.\n- Sort the result descendingly using `sort` .
cat words.txt | tr -s \' \' \'\\n\' | sort |  uniq -c | awk \'{printf("%s %s\\n", $2, $1)}\' | sort -k2nr
tr -s " " < words.txt | tr " " $\'\\n\' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | sed -r "s/\\s*([0-9]+)\\s*([a-z]+)/\\2 \\1/" | grep -e "[a-z]"

egrep -o "\w+" words.txt | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | awk '{print $2 " " $1}'

Commands explanation
egrep -o "\w+" words.txt
select words(regex words) only. So anything that is not a word is filtered out. things like "\n\n"

sort | uniq -c | sort -nr
first sort is needed because uniq assumes the list is sorted
uniq -c counts occurences of each word
sort -nr sorts final result as nums and in reverse order so that most frequent words appear on top

awk '{print $2 " " $1}'
with out this statement, the result would be : frequency word
with awk, we are able to take first argument (frequency) and second argument (word) and reverse their order by printing the second one (word) first, then first one(frequency) second.
cat words.txt | sed \':a;N;$!ba;s/\\n/ /g\' | sed \'s/ \\+/\\n/g\' | sort | uniq -c | sort -k1nr | awk \'{print $2, $1}\'\n![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/xiaozhi_y/image_1556540351.png)\n
cat words.txt|xargs -n 1|sort|uniq -c|sort -nr|awk \'{print $2" "$1}\'
tr < words.txt -cs "[a-z]" "\\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k1nr | awk '{print $2, $1}'\n\nIt is easy, huh?

rm -f sorted

while read line
do
  for var in $line
   do
    word_cnt=`grep -w -o "$var" words.txt | wc -w`
    echo "$var ::: $word_cnt >> sorted.txt"
   done
done < words.txt

sort -u sorted.txt

tr -s " " < words.txt | tr " " $\'\\n\' | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | sed -r "s/\\s*([0-9]+)\\s*([a-z]+)/\\2 \\1/" | grep -e "[a-z]"

egrep -o "\w+" words.txt | sort | uniq -c | sort -nr | awk '{print $2 " " $1}'

Commands explanation
egrep -o "\w+" words.txt
select words(regex words) only. So anything that is not a word is filtered out. things like "\n\n"

sort | uniq -c | sort -nr
first sort is needed because uniq assumes the list is sorted
uniq -c counts occurences of each word
sort -nr sorts final result as nums and in reverse order so that most frequent words appear on top

awk '{print $2 " " $1}'
with out this statement, the result would be : frequency word
with awk, we are able to take first argument (frequency) and second argument (word) and reverse their order by printing the second one (word) first, then first one(frequency) second.
cat words.txt | sed \':a;N;$!ba;s/\\n/ /g\' | sed \'s/ \\+/\\n/g\' | sort | uniq -c | sort -k1nr | awk \'{print $2, $1}\'\n![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/xiaozhi_y/image_1556540351.png)\n
cat words.txt|xargs -n 1|sort|uniq -c|sort -nr|awk \'{print $2" "$1}\'
tr < words.txt -cs "[a-z]" "\\n" | sort | uniq -c | sort -k1nr | awk '{print $2, $1}'\n\nIt is easy, huh?

It will use another file, just to remove duplicates in the file.

rm -f sorted

while read line
do
  for var in $line
   do
    word_cnt=`grep -w -o "$var" words.txt | wc -w`
    echo "$var ::: $word_cnt >> sorted.txt"
   done
done < words.txt

sort -u sorted.txt
